column1: Umm Al Quwain (UAQ; Arabic: أم القيوين‎; pronounced [ʔumː alqajˈwajn]) is one of the seven constituent emirates in the United Arab Emirates
column2: located in the north of the country. It is the second smallest and least populous Emirate in the UAE. The closest body of water near it is the Persian Gulf. The emirate is ruled by Saud bin Rashid Al Mualla. The current crown prince is Rashid bin Saud bin Rashid Al Mua'lla
column3: and the deputy ruler is Abdullah bin Rashid Al Mualla III. It had 72
column4: 000 inhabitants in 2007 and has an area of 770 km2 (300 sq mi).The emirate consists in the main of the coastal city of Umm Al Quwain and the inland oasis town of Falaj Al Mualla
column5: some 30 km (19 mi) from the coast.Unlike some of its neighbours
column6: Umm Al Quwain has not made any significant find of oil or gas in its territory and depends on revenue from hotels
column8: fisheries and general trading activities as well as the Umm Al Quwain Free Trade Zone (UAQFTZ) based at Port Ahmed Bin Rashid.

column1: A number of government initiatives and strategies have been put in place to incentivise growth in trade and industrial activity in the emirate
column2: including a 2018 move to reduce government fees to business and waive fines and violations levied against businesses which had not renewed their trade licenses.

column1: == Etymology ==

Multiple theories have been established on the etymology of the name Umm Al Quwain. The most accepted meaning is that the name means "mother of the two powers" - from the phrase "Umm Al Quwatain" (Arabic: ام القوتين‎
column3: lit. 'The mother of two powers'). The two powers here are usually indicated as the two forms of geographical powers. Locals describe it as the richness of activities both on land and water
column4: others refer to it as the two powers of economy and agriculture. Another theory is that the word "Quwain" is inspired by an Arabic word "Qawn" meaning ‘iron‘. Therefore
column5: some believe that it may refer to iron in the place.

column1: == History and prehistory ==
Umm Al Quwain holds significant archaeological interest
column2: with major finds at both Tell Abraq and Ed-Dur pointing to significant Ancient Near Eastern Cities. Arrowheads and other polished flint tools have been unearthed in various sites across the UAE while pieces of Ubaid Age pottery have been unearthed along the shores of the emirate. All evidence obtained so far indicate that contact with Mesopotamia existed as early as the 5th millennium BC
column4: did not emerge until the 3rd century BC.

column1: Finds at both Tell Abraq and Ed-Dur show habitation in the area throughout the Bronze Age
column3: through the Umm Al Nar period and the later Wadi Suq and Iron I
column4: II and III ages. Finds also link Ed-Dur with the inland settlement of Mleiha
column5: especially distinctive burials of animals with their heads turned back on their bodies. Significant trading links with both the Western Sumerian culture and the Eastern Indus Valley culture are displayed at these sites
column6: with the semi-nomadic Magan people smelting bronze mined in the Hajar Mountains and then shipping the smelted ore.

column1: Macedonian coinage unearthed at Ed-Dur dates back to Alexander the Great
column2: while hundreds of coins have been found bearing the name of Abi'el. In March 2019
column7: dating back to the 1st century CE
column8: were unearthed here. It is thought Ed-Dur is the site of Omana
column9: mentioned by both Pliny and Strabo as an important town in the Lower Persian Gulf.During the Bronze Age
column11: with dates being the prominent crop. Wheat
column12: millet and other grains were also cultivated wherever there was enough water for irrigation. It is now widely believed that the climate during the period was more temperate than now.

column1: === 20th century ===
Umm Al Quwain was the site of a fort built in 1768 by the founder of the modern Al Mualla dynasty
column2: Sheikh Rashid bin Majid of the Al Ali tribe.On 8 January 1820
column3: Sheikh Abdullah bin Rashid signed the General Maritime Treaty with the United Kingdom
column4: thus accepting a British protectorate in order to keep the Ottoman Turks out. Like Ajman
column7: its position on the route to India made it important enough to be recognized as a salute state with a three gun salute.By 1908
column8: J. G. Lorimer's famous survey of the Trucial Coast
column9: the Gazetteer of the Persian Gulf
column11: had Umm Al Quwain listed as a town of some 5
column12: 000 inhabitants and identified as the major boat-building centre on the coast
column13: producing some 20 boats a year compared to 10 in Dubai and 5 in Sharjah.On 2 December 1971
column14: Sheikh Ahmad bin Rashid joined its neighbors Abu Dhabi
column17: Ajman and Fujairah in forming the United Arab Emirates
column18: with Ras Al-Khaimah joining later in early 1972.

column1: ==== Petrochemicals ====

The American oil company Occidental acquired a concession to search for oil in Umm Al Quwain territorial waters on 19 November 1969. Occidental proposed drilling an exploratory well nine miles from the island of Abu Musa in the Persian Gulf in what it considered to be Umm Al Quwain waters. However
column2: this conflicted with a 12-mile territorial limit claimed by Sharjah. On 15 May 1970
column3: the British authorities referred the dispute to arbitration
column4: but ruled that Occidental could continue to drill. On 20 May
column5: Iran informed the British that it laid claim to Abu Musa and the two Tunbs' islands
column6: and would intercede if Occidental continued to drill. The British proposed a three-month suspension of drilling pending the outcome of arbitration
column7: a decision enforced by a British minesweeper
column8: which intercepted Occidental's drilling platform and moved it out of the area.The agreement between Sharjah and Iran over the island of Abu Musa
column9: made on 29 November 1971 and the subsequent invasion of the islands on 30 November 1971 rendered the issue moot. Occidental would never find oil under its Umm Al Quwain concession.

column1: === Rulers ===
The successive rulers of Umm Al Quwain were:
1768–1820: Sheikh Rashid bin Majid Al Mualla
1820–1853: Sheikh Abdullah bin Rashid Al Mualla (b.1794)
1853–1873: Sheikh Ali bin Abdullah Al Mualla (b.1824 – d.1873)
1873–1904: Sheikh Ahmad bin Abdullah Al Mualla (b. 1832 – d. 1904)
13 June 1904 – 1922: Sheikh Rashid bin Ahmad Al Mualla (b. 1876 – d. 1922)
1922 – October 1923: Sheikh Abdullah bin Rashid Al Mualla II
October 1923 – 9 February 1929: Sheikh Hamad bin Ibrahim Al Mualla
9 February 1929 – 21 February 1981: Sheikh Ahmad bin Rashid Al Mualla (b. 1904 – d. 1981)
21 February 1981 – 2 January 2009: Sheikh Rashid bin Ahmad Al Mualla II (b. 1932 – d. 2009)
2 January 2009–present: Sheikh Saud bin Rashid Al Mualla (b. 1952)
== Climate and environment ==
During November to March
column2: the average temperature is 27 °C (81 °F) by day and 15 °C (59 °F) at night
column3: but it can rise to over 40 °C (104 °F) in the peak of the summer and when humidity levels are high. The rainfall is minimal and averages 42 mm (1.7 in) a year. The coastline experiences cooling sea breezes during the day.

column1: Al Sinniyah island
column2: close to the city of Umm Al Quwain is home to the UAE's largest Socotra cormorant colony
column4: 000 pairs making it the third largest colony in the world. Arabian gazelles have been introduced to Sinniyah and appear to be prospering. Marine life is remarkable for its abundance and diversity. Blacktip reef sharks patrol the outer shoreline
column5: while green turtles are ubiquitous in the inner leads in particular. Between Al Sinniyah and the mainland is Khor Al Beidah
column6: an expansive area of sand and mud flats of international importance for its waterfowl. Although not formally protected
column9: is one of the largest areas of undisturbed and varied coastal environment remaining anywhere in the UAE.

column1: == Culture ==
The UAE culture mainly revolves around the religion of Islam and traditional Arab culture. The influence of Islamic and Arab culture on its architecture
column4: cuisine and lifestyle are very prominent as well. Five times every day
column5: Muslims are called to prayer from the minarets of mosques which are scattered around the country. Since 2006
column7: as a compromise between Friday's holiness to Muslims and the Western weekend of Saturday-Sunday.

column1: == Tourism ==
Umm Al Quwain Fort: A fort which was once home to the emirate's ruler and guarded the entrance to the old town
column2: overseeing the sea on one side and the creek on the other. It eventually became a police station then a museum. The museum now houses artifacts found at important nearby sites including Ed-Dur and houses a collection of weapons that were used through the emirate's history. It is located near a Masjid (Mosque) in Umm Al Quwain Bazaar.

column1: Old Harbour: An old harbour located in the old town overlooking the traditional dhow building yard where skilled craftsmen continue to assemble these traditional boats. The harbor is surrounded by old coral stone houses that display features of the original architecture and intricate sculptured plaster work.
Islands of Umm Al Quwain: Islands that lie to the east of the mainland peninsula on a unique stretch of coastline consisting of sandy islands surrounded by dense mangrove forests
column2: separated by a series of creeks. The largest of the seven islands is Al Sinniyah
column3: followed by Jazirat Al Ghallah and Al Keabe
column4: all of which are visible from the old town. Tucked in between these and the coastal plains are the smaller islands of Al Sow
column7: Al Chewria and Al Harmala. The Madaar creek that runs between the islands provides a navigable waterway for fisherman even at low tide when the average depth is less than a few feet.

column1: Ed-Dur: Located to the north of Umm Al Quwain
column2: the ancient near eastern city of Ed-Dur is considered the largest pre-Islamic site on the Persian Gulf coast. There are two public monuments at Al-Dour
column3: a small square fort with round corner towers and a small square temple dedicated to the Semitic sun god Shamash. The site is not open to the public.

column1: Dreamland Aqua Park: the largest water park in the UAE is located on the coastline of Umm Al Quwain; about 40 minutes drive from Dubai
column3: 000 m2 (62 acres) expanse of landscaped gardens and over 30 rides
column5: and attractions. The Park is operated all year round with a daily capacity of ten thousand visitors.
